Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down. He raised his hands over his head in a sort of mute despair, and then beat his palms together in a helpless way; finally he sat down on a chair, and putting his hands before his face, began to sob, with loud, dry sobs that seemed to come from the very racking of his heart. Then he raised his arms again, as though appealing to the whole universe. “God! God! God!” he said. “What have we done, what has this poor thing done, that we are so sore beset? Is there fate amongst us still, sent down from the pagan world of old, that such things must be, and in such way? This poor mother, all unknowing, and all for the best as she think, does such thing as lose her daughter body and soul; and we must not tell her, we must not even warn her, or she die, and then both die. Oh, how we are beset! How are all the powers of the devils against us!” Suddenly he jumped to his feet. “Come,” he said, “come, we must see and act. Devils or no devils, or all the devils at once, it matters not; we fight him all the same.” He went to the hall-door for his bag; and together we went up to Lucy’s room.
Once again I drew up the blind, whilst Van Helsing went towards the bed. This time he did not start as he looked on the poor face with the same awful, waxen pallor as before. He wore a look of stern sadness and infinite pity.
“As I expected,” he murmured, with that hissing inspiration of his which meant so much. Without a word he went and locked the door, and then began to set out on the little table the instruments for yet another operation of transfusion of blood. I had long ago recognised the necessity, and begun to take off my coat, but he stopped me with a warning hand. “No!” he said. “To-day you must operate. I shall provide. You are weakened already.” As he spoke he took off his coat and rolled up his shirt-sleeve.
Again the operation; again the narcotic; again some return of colour to the ashy cheeks, and the regular breathing of healthy sleep. This time I watched whilst Van Helsing recruited himself and rested.
Presently he took an opportunity of telling Mrs. Westenra that she must not remove anything from Lucy’s room without consulting him; that the flowers were of medicinal value, and that the breathing of their odour was a part of the system of cure. Then he took over the care of the case himself, saying that he would watch this night and the next and would send me word when to come.
After another hour Lucy waked from her sleep, fresh and bright and seemingly not much the worse for her terrible ordeal.
What does it all mean? I am beginning to wonder if my long habit of life amongst the insane is beginning to tell upon my own brain.

“She is dying. It will not be long now. It may be much shorter than we think. Quick! Get ready the things for the transfusion. We must brave it again, for her sake, and if it is to be the last time, then so be it.”

“To-night I shall stay here myself. You must go to bed, for to-morrow night you must return, and you will need all your strength.”  

Later in the day Lucy woke from her sleep, fresh and bright and seemingly not much the worse for her terrible ordeal.

Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down. The great man, whose strength and wisdom had been our guiding light through the horrors we had faced, crumpled before my eyes. His broad shoulders sagged, his face—usually so animated with energy—went slack, and his eyes, those piercing eyes that had seen so much and yet never wavered, filled with tears. He sank into a chair, his hands trembling as they covered his face, and a low, shuddering sob escaped him.  

I stood frozen, unsure of what to do. This was not the Van Helsing I knew—the fearless hunter, the relentless scholar, the man who had faced the unspeakable with unshaken resolve. This was a man broken by grief, by the weight of all we had endured. I had seen him exhausted, I had seen him grave, but never like this. Never so utterly defeated.  

Slowly, I approached him, placing a hesitant hand on his shoulder. "Professor," I said softly, my own voice thick with emotion. "What is it? What has happened?"  

For a long moment, he did not answer. Then, with a great effort, he lowered his hands and looked up at me. His face was haggard, his expression one of such profound sorrow that it chilled me to the bone. "It is Mina," he whispered. "Our dear, brave Mina. The curse has taken deeper hold than we feared."  

My heart clenched at his words. Mina Harker, that noble and gentle soul, had been fighting the vampiric taint with all her strength. We had all clung to hope, believing that if anyone could resist the darkness, it was she. But now, seeing Van Helsing’s despair, I knew the worst had come to pass.  

"I have failed her," he murmured, his voice barely audible. "All my knowledge, all my skill—it was not enough. The evil is too strong."  

I had never imagined hearing such words from him. Van Helsing, who had always been our rock, our unshakable leader, now doubted himself. The realization struck me like a physical blow. If he had lost hope, what chance did the rest of us have?  

But then, something within me rebelled against the despair. I tightened my grip on his shoulder. "No," I said firmly. "You have not failed her. None of us have. We will fight for her until the very end. You taught us that, Professor. You taught us never to surrender."  

For a moment, he simply stared at me, as if seeing me for the first time. Then, slowly, the fire returned to his eyes. He drew in a deep breath, straightened his back, and wiped the tears from his face. "You are right, my friend," he said, his voice gaining strength. "We must not yield. Not while there is still breath in our bodies."  

And just like that, the Van Helsing I knew was back. The moment of weakness had passed, replaced once more by the indomitable spirit that had carried us through so much. But in that brief glimpse of his vulnerability, I had seen something precious—the humanity beneath the legend. It made me admire him all the more.  

For even the strongest of men may falter, but it is the courage to rise again that defines them. And rise he did, ready to face whatever horrors still awaited us in the shadows.

events.text_segment: 17 September.—Four days and nights of peace. I am getting so strong again that I hardly know myself. It is as if I had passed through some long nightmare, and had just awakened to see the beautiful sunshine and feel the fresh air of the morning around me. I have a dim half-remembrance of long, anxious times of waiting and fearing; darkness in which there was not even the pain of hope to make present distress more poignant: and then long spells of oblivion, and the rising back to life as a diver coming up through a great press of water. Since, however, Dr. Van Helsing has been with me, all this bad dreaming seems to have passed away; the noises that used to frighten me out of my wits—the flapping against the windows, the distant voices which seemed so close to me, the harsh sounds that came from I know not where and commanded me to do I know not what—have all ceased. I go to bed now without any fear of sleep. I do not even try to keep awake. I have grown quite fond of the garlic, and a boxful arrives for me every day from Haarlem. To-night Dr. Van Helsing is going away, as he has to be for a day in Amsterdam. But I need not be watched; I am well enough to be left alone. Thank God for mother’s sake, and dear Arthur’s, and for all our friends who have been so kind! I shall not even feel the change, for last night Dr. Van Helsing slept in his chair a lot of the time. I found him asleep twice when I awoke; but I did not fear to go to sleep again, although the boughs or bats or something napped almost angrily against the window-panes.

**17 September.—Four days and nights of peace.**  

The respite has been a blessing, though I cannot shake the unease that lingers like a shadow. Since my last entry, the Count has not disturbed me, nor have I heard the faintest whisper of his presence. The castle remains silent, save for the howling wind that rattles the ancient stones.  

I have used this time to explore further, though my movements are still confined. The library, vast and dust-laden, has become my refuge. Among the moldering tomes, I found maps of Transylvania and histories of the Dracula lineage—dark chronicles of war and bloodshed. The more I read, the more I fear the truth of my host’s nature.  

My health, at least, has improved. The wounds on my neck have faded, though a lingering weakness persists. I eat what little food is left for me—coarse bread, cheese, and the occasional flask of wine—but my appetite wanes with each passing day. Sleep comes fitfully, haunted by dreams I dare not recount.  

Last night, I ventured down a winding staircase I had not yet dared to descend. The air grew colder, thick with the scent of earth and decay. At its end, I found a crypt—rows of stone coffins, one of which lay open. Inside, the Count rested, his face as pale as death, his lips stained crimson. I fled before he could wake, my heart pounding like a drum.  

I am certain now: he is no man. And this castle is no sanctuary—it is a tomb, and I its prisoner.  

God help me. I must find a way to escape before he decides my fate.  

**Jonathan Harker.**

events.title: The Escaped Wolf 'Bersicker' and the Zookeeper's Ominous Encounter
detailed_summary: A newspaper reporter interviews Thomas Bilder, a zookeeper, about an escaped wolf named Bersicker.
Bilder, after some initial reluctance and playful banter, agrees to discuss the matter.
He describes Bersicker as a normally calm wolf, making his escape surprising.
Bilder recounts an incident prior to the escape: a tall, thin man with a hooked nose, pointed beard, red eyes, and sharp teeth was near the wolf enclosure.
The wolves, particularly Bersicker, became agitated by this man's presence.
The mysterious man, with an insolent smile, denied upsetting the wolves and then, surprisingly, joined Bilder in stroking Bersicker's ears, claiming familiarity with such animals.
The man, dressed in white kid gloves, politely departed after stating he wasn't in the animal trade but had "made pets of several."
Bersicker watched the man leave and then remained subdued in a corner for the rest of the evening.

events.text_segment:
THE ESCAPED WOLF.
PERILOUS ADVENTURE OF OUR INTERVIEWER.
Interview with the Keeper in the Zoölogical Gardens.
After many inquiries and almost as many refusals, and perpetually using the words “Pall Mall Gazette” as a sort of talisman, I managed to find the keeper of the section of the Zoölogical Gardens in which the wolf department is included. Thomas Bilder lives in one of the cottages in the enclosure behind the elephant-house, and was just sitting down to his tea when I found him. Thomas and his wife are hospitable folk, elderly, and without children, and if the specimen I enjoyed of their hospitality be of the average kind, their lives must be pretty comfortable. The keeper would not enter on what he called “business” until the supper was over, and we were all satisfied. Then when the table was cleared, and he had lit his pipe, he said:—
“Now, sir, you can go on and arsk me what you want. You’ll excoose me refoosin’ to talk of perfeshunal subjects afore meals. I gives the wolves and the jackals and the hyenas in all our section their tea afore I begins to arsk them questions.”
“How do you mean, ask them questions?” I queried, wishful to get him into a talkative humour.
“’Ittin’ of them over the ’ead with a pole is one way; scratchin’ of their hears is another, when gents as is flush wants a bit of a show-orf to their gals. I don’t so much mind the fust—the ’ittin’ with a pole afore I chucks in their dinner; but I waits till they’ve ’ad their sherry and kawffee, so to speak, afore I tries on with the ear-scratchin’. Mind you,” he added philosophically, “there’s a deal of the same nature in us as in them theer animiles. Here’s you a-comin’ and arskin’ of me questions about my business, and I that grumpy-like that only for your bloomin’ ’arf-quid I’d ’a’ seen you blowed fust ’fore I’d answer. Not even when you arsked me sarcastic-like if I’d like you to arsk the Superintendent if you might arsk me questions. Without offence did I tell yer to go to ’ell?”
“You did.”
“An’ when you said you’d report me for usin’ of obscene language that was ’ittin’ me over the ’ead; but the ’arf-quid made that all right. I weren’t a-goin’ to fight, so I waited for the food, and did with my ’owl as the wolves, and lions, and tigers does. But, Lor’ love yer ’art, now that the old ’ooman has stuck a chunk of her tea-cake in me, an’ rinsed me out with her bloomin’ old teapot, and I’ve lit hup, you may scratch my ears for all you’re worth, and won’t git even a growl out of me. Drive along with your questions. I know what yer a-comin’ at, that ’ere escaped wolf.”
“Exactly. I want you to give me your view of it. Just tell me how it happened; and when I know the facts I’ll get you to say what you consider was the cause of it, and how you think the whole affair will end.”
“All right, guv’nor. This ’ere is about the ’ole story. That ’ere wolf what we called Bersicker was one of three grey ones that came from Norway to Jamrach’s, which we bought off him four years ago. He was a nice well-behaved wolf, that never gave no trouble to talk of. I’m more surprised at ’im for wantin’ to get out nor any other animile in the place. But, there, you can’t trust wolves no more nor women.”
“Don’t you mind him, sir!” broke in Mrs. Tom, with a cheery laugh. “’E’s got mindin’ the animiles so long that blest if he ain’t like a old wolf ’isself! But there ain’t no ’arm in ’im.”
“Well, sir, it was about two hours after feedin’ yesterday when I first hear my disturbance. I was makin’ up a litter in the monkey-house for a young puma which is ill; but when I heard the yelpin’ and ’owlin’ I kem away straight. There was Bersicker a-tearin’ like a mad thing at the bars as if he wanted to get out. There wasn’t much people about that day, and close at hand was only one man, a tall, thin chap, with a ’ook nose and a pointed beard, with a few white hairs runnin’ through it. He had a ’ard, cold look and red eyes, and I took a sort of mislike to him, for it seemed as if it was ’im as they was hirritated at. He ’ad white kid gloves on ’is ’ands, and he pointed out the animiles to me and says: ‘Keeper, these wolves seem upset at something.’
“‘Maybe it’s you,’ says I, for I did not like the airs as he give ’isself. He didn’t git angry, as I ’oped he would, but he smiled a kind of insolent smile, with a mouth full of white, sharp teeth. ‘Oh no, they wouldn’t like me,’ ’e says.
“‘Ow yes, they would,’ says I, a-imitatin’ of him. ‘They always likes a bone or two to clean their teeth on about tea-time, which you ’as a bagful.’
“Well, it was a odd thing, but when the animiles see us a-talkin’ they lay down, and when I went over to Bersicker he let me stroke his ears same as ever. That there man kem over, and blessed but if he didn’t put in his hand and stroke the old wolf’s ears too!
“‘Tyke care,’ says I. ‘Bersicker is quick.’
“‘Never mind,’ he says. ‘I’m used to ’em!’
“‘Are you in the business yourself?’ I says, tyking off my ’at, for a man what trades in wolves, anceterer, is a good friend to keepers.
“‘No,’ says he, ‘not exactly in the business, but I ’ave made pets of several.’ And with that he lifts his ’at as perlite as a lord, and walks away. Old Bersicker kep’ a-lookin’ arter ’im till ’e was out of sight, and then went and lay down in a corner and wouldn’t come hout the ’ole hevening.

“Ah, them’s my speciality. There ain’t a wolf in the ’ole bloomin’ Gardens wot I don’t know, and there ain’t one wot don’t know me. “‘Certainly, sir,’ says I; ‘this way, sir.’ And I takes him round to where Bersicker was a-lyin’ down asleep.  

“‘That’s a fine wolf,’ says he.  

“‘Yes, sir,’ says I, ‘he’s a good un.’  

“‘He looks quiet,’ says he.  

“‘Oh, he is quiet,’ says I. ‘He’s been fed, and he’s had his exercise, and he ain’t got no cause to be otherwise.’  

“Then all of a sudden he lets out a yell fit to wake the dead, and before I could stop him he jumps into the cage. Bersicker, who was lying down, jumps up and runs to the bars, and the stranger puts out his hand and strokes him.  

“‘What’s that for?’ says I.  

“‘Oh,’ says he, ‘I’ve made pets of several of them.’  

“‘You have, have you?’ says I. ‘Well, you’re a cool hand, anyhow.’  

“Then he smiles, insolent-like, and says, ‘Oh, I’ve been about a bit, and I know how to manage them.’  

“‘Do you?’ says I. ‘P’raps you’ll tell me how you does it.’  

“‘Certainly,’ says he, ‘when I’ve more time.’  

“Then he walks away, and Bersicker, who’d been watching him, goes and lies down in a corner and never takes no more notice of him nor of me.  

“Well, I didn’t think no more of it till next morning, when Bersicker was gone, and the whole place was upside down with the keepers and the police a-huntin’ high and low for him.”

The following account is taken from the *Dailygraph*, a local newspaper in Whitby, detailing the strange and unsettling events surrounding the escape of a wolf from the traveling menagerie. The incident, though seemingly minor at first, would later prove to be of great significance in the unfolding horrors that befell the town—horrors tied inextricably to the arrival of the mysterious Count Dracula.  

### **The Incident at the Menagerie**  

On the evening of August 8th, the traveling menagerie, which had been exhibiting a collection of wild animals in Whitby, became the scene of an alarming disturbance. Among the creatures on display was a large and particularly fierce wolf, described by witnesses as unusually intelligent and restless. The beast had been a source of fascination—and unease—for many visitors, its yellow eyes seeming to watch the crowds with an almost human cunning.  

Shortly after nightfall, the wolf managed to break free from its cage. The exact manner of its escape remains unclear, though some attendants later claimed that the lock appeared to have been tampered with, as if someone—or something—had deliberately released it. The animal, instead of fleeing into the countryside, lingered near the town, its howls echoing through the streets in a manner that chilled the blood of those who heard it.  

### **Panic in Whitby**  

News of the wolf’s escape spread quickly, and the townsfolk were advised to remain indoors. Several individuals reported seeing the beast prowling near the churchyard or along the cliffs, its gaunt form silhouetted against the moonlight. One old fisherman swore he saw it standing motionless atop the East Cliff, staring out to sea as if awaiting something—or someone.  

The most disturbing account came from a local woman, who claimed the wolf had paused outside her cottage, its eyes gleaming with an unnatural light. She insisted that it did not behave like a wild animal, but rather as if it were under some sinister guidance.  

### **The Wolf and the Demeter**  

It was not long after the wolf’s escape that the Russian schooner *Demeter* ran aground in Whitby harbor, its crew missing or dead, its cargo hold filled with boxes of earth—and its only living passenger, a great black dog, leaping ashore and vanishing into the night. The timing of these events struck many as more than mere coincidence.  

Some whispered that the wolf had been a harbinger, a creature sent to prepare the way for something far darker. Others, recalling old superstitions, muttered of werewolves and demons. The local authorities dismissed such talk as foolishness, but the unease lingered.  

### **A Sinister Connection**  

In the days that followed, strange occurrences multiplied in Whitby. Livestock were found drained of blood. A sleepwalking woman, Lucy Westenra, began exhibiting bizarre symptoms, her strength fading as if preyed upon by some unseen force. And always, at the edge of perception, there was the sense of being watched—of something ancient and malevolent moving among them.  

Only later would the full significance of the escaped wolf become clear. For those who pieced together the fragments of the mystery, the beast had not been merely an animal, but a servant—a creature bound to the will of Count Dracula himself. Its escape had not been an accident, but a carefully orchestrated step in the vampire’s plan to establish himself in England.  

### **Conclusion**  

The escaped wolf was but one thread in the dark tapestry of events that heralded Dracula’s arrival. Its brief, terrifying presence in Whitby served as a warning—one that went unheeded until it was too late. By the time the true nature of the threat was understood, the Count had already begun his reign of terror, his influence spreading like a shadow across the land.  

And so, what began as a curious incident in a small seaside town became a pivotal moment in a battle against an ancient evil—one that would demand courage, sacrifice, and the unyielding resolve of those who dared to stand against the night.  

**THE END.**

events.title: Bersicker's Moonlight Escape, Return, and the Zookeeper's Mundane Explanation
detailed_summary: Bilder continues his account, stating that on the night of the escape, as the moon rose, all the wolves began howling despite no apparent cause, except perhaps someone calling a dog nearby.
Around midnight, Bilder discovered Bersicker's cage rails broken and the cage empty.
He dismisses a gardener's delayed report of seeing a large grey dog as unreliable.
When asked for his theory on the escape, Bilder humorously suggests the wolf escaped simply because it wanted to.

After being offered another payment, Bilder opines that the wolf is likely hiding scared, perhaps in a coal cellar, and might become dangerous if it can't find food, possibly even attacking an unattended baby.
Suddenly, Bersicker, the escaped wolf, reappears at the window.
Bilder calmly lets the wolf in; the animal is peaceful and penitent.
Bilder examines Bersicker, finding his head cut and full of broken glass, attributing the injury to climbing a wall topped with broken bottles.
He locks Bersicker back in his cage with a large piece of meat and goes to report the wolf's return.
The interviewer departs to file his exclusive story.

Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling. There warn’t nothing for them to ’owl at. There warn’t no one near, except some one that was evidently a-callin’ a dog somewheres out back of the gardings in the Park road. Once or twice I went out to see that all was right, and it was, and then the ’owling stopped. Just before twelve o’clock I just took a look round afore turnin’ in, an’, bust me, but when I kem opposite to old Bersicker’s cage I see the rails broken and twisted about and the cage empty. And that’s all I know for certing.”
“Did any one else see anything?”
“One of our gard’ners was a-comin’ ’ome about that time from a ’armony, when he sees a big grey dog comin’ out through the garding ’edges. At least, so he says, but I don’t give much for it myself, for if he did ’e never said a word about it to his missis when ’e got ’ome, and it was only after the escape of the wolf was made known, and we had been up all night-a-huntin’ of the Park for Bersicker, that he remembered seein’ anything. My own belief was that the ’armony ’ad got into his ’ead.”
“Now, Mr. Bilder, can you account in any way for the escape of the wolf?”
“Well, sir,” he said, with a suspicious sort of modesty, “I think I can; but I don’t know as ’ow you’d be satisfied with the theory.”
“Certainly I shall. If a man like you, who knows the animals from experience, can’t hazard a good guess at any rate, who is even to try?”
“Well then, sir, I accounts for it this way; it seems to me that ’ere wolf escaped—simply because he wanted to get out.”
From the hearty way that both Thomas and his wife laughed at the joke I could see that it had done service before, and that the whole explanation was simply an elaborate sell. I couldn’t cope in badinage with the worthy Thomas, but I thought I knew a surer way to his heart, so I said:—
“Now, Mr. Bilder, we’ll consider that first half-sovereign worked off, and this brother of his is waiting to be claimed when you’ve told me what you think will happen.”
“Right y’are, sir,” he said briskly. “Ye’ll excoose me, I know, for a-chaffin’ of ye, but the old woman here winked at me, which was as much as telling me to go on.”
“Well, I never!” said the old lady.
“My opinion is this: that ’ere wolf is a-’idin’ of, somewheres. The gard’ner wot didn’t remember said he was a-gallopin’ northward faster than a horse could go; but I don’t believe him, for, yer see, sir, wolves don’t gallop no more nor dogs does, they not bein’ built that way. Wolves is fine things in a storybook, and I dessay when they gets in packs and does be chivyin’ somethin’ that’s more afeared than they is they can make a devil of a noise and chop it up, whatever it is. But, Lor’ bless you, in real life a wolf is only a low creature, not half so clever or bold as a good dog; and not half a quarter so much fight in ’im. This one ain’t been used to fightin’ or even to providin’ for hisself, and more like he’s somewhere round the Park a-’idin’ an’ a-shiverin’ of, and, if he thinks at all, wonderin’ where he is to get his breakfast from; or maybe he’s got down some area and is in a coal-cellar. My eye, won’t some cook get a rum start when she sees his green eyes a-shining at her out of the dark! If he can’t get food he’s bound to look for it, and mayhap he may chance to light on a butcher’s shop in time. If he doesn’t, and some nursemaid goes a-walkin’ orf with a soldier, leavin’ of the hinfant in the perambulator—well, then I shouldn’t be surprised if the census is one babby the less. That’s all.”
I was handing him the half-sovereign, when something came bobbing up against the window, and Mr. Bilder’s face doubled its natural length with surprise.
“God bless me!” he said. “If there ain’t old Bersicker come back by ’isself!”
He went to the door and opened it; a most unnecessary proceeding it seemed to me. I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us; a personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea.
After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I should of a dog. The animal itself was as peaceful and well-behaved as that father of all picture-wolves—Red Riding Hood’s quondam friend, whilst moving her confidence in masquerade.
The whole scene was an unutterable mixture of comedy and pathos. The wicked wolf that for half a day had paralysed London and set all the children in the town shivering in their shoes, was there in a sort of penitent mood, and was received and petted like a sort of vulpine prodigal son. Old Bilder examined him all over with most tender solicitude, and when he had finished with his penitent said:—
“There, I knew the poor old chap would get into some kind of trouble; didn’t I say it all along? Here’s his head all cut and full of broken glass. ’E’s been a-gettin’ over some bloomin’ wall or other. It’s a shyme that people are allowed to top their walls with broken bottles. This ’ere’s what comes of it. Come along, Bersicker.”
He took the wolf and locked him up in a cage, with a piece of meat that satisfied, in quantity at any rate, the elementary conditions of the fatted calf, and went off to report.
I came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo.

**The Howling of the Wolves**  

Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling. A dreadful sound it were, too—long, mournful cries what seemed to rise from the very bowels o’ the earth. I’ve ’eard wolves afore, mind, but never like this. It were as if they was callin’ to somethin’—or *someone*.  

I was sittin’ by the fire in me little cottage, tryin’ to mend an old boot, when the first ’owl come. It sent such a chill down me spine that I near dropped me needle. Then another joined in, and another, till the whole forest was alive with their wailin’. I went to the window, pullin’ aside the ragged curtain, and peered out into the blackness. The moon hung low, bloated and yellow like a sickly eye, castin’ queer shadows ’cross the snow.  

That’s when I seen ’im.  

A tall figure, cloaked in black, standin’ at the edge o’ the trees. He weren’t movin’, just starin’ straight at me cottage. I couldn’t see his face proper, but I *felt* his eyes—cold as death, they was. The wolves kept up their ’owlin’, but now it sounded different—like they was answerin’ to ’im.  

Me heart near stopped. I’ve lived in these parts all me life, and I know the tales. The peasants whisper of *him*—the Master what walks by night, what commands the beasts and the shadows. They say he can call the wolves to do his biddin’, that they’re his servants, same as the bats and the mist.  

I made the sign o’ the cross quick as I could and stepped back from the window. But when I looked again, he was gone. Only the wolves remained, their cries growin’ louder, more frantic, like they was bein’ driven mad.  

Then—silence.  

Not a sound, not so much as a twig crackin’. The sudden quiet were worse than the noise. I stood there, frozen, listenin’ to me own breathin’. Then, soft as a whisper, came a *knock* at me door.  

Three slow, deliberate raps.  

I ain’t ashamed to say me legs near gave out from under me. There ain’t a soul for miles in these woods—not at this hour, not in this cold. And no man walks abroad when the wolves are runnin’ wild.  

“Who—who’s there?” I called, tryin’ to keep me voice from shakin’.  

No answer. Just another knock, harder this time.  

I grabbed the old crucifix from the wall and held it tight. “In the name o’ God, speak!”  

A low laugh come from the other side o’ the door—a sound what made me blood turn to ice. Then a voice, smooth as silk but cold as the grave:  

*“Open to me.”*  

I knew then I were done for. That weren’t no livin’ man out there. That were *him*—the one they fear to name.  

The door rattled in its frame, like somethin’ powerful were testin’ its strength. The crucifix in me hand trembled, but I held it up high. “Begone!” I shouted. “Ye’ve no power here!”  

For a moment, nothin’ happened. Then—slowly—the pressure on the door eased. The wolves began their ’owlin’ again, but this time it sounded farther off, like they was retreatin’ into the forest.  

I didn’t sleep a wink the rest o’ the night. Just sat by the fire, clutchin’ me crucifix, listenin’ to the wind moan through the trees.  

Come dawn, I went outside. There in the snow, right before me door, were footprints—but not like any man’s. They was long and narrow, with no sign o’ boots. And leadin’ away from ’em, clear as day, were the tracks o’ wolves.  

I packed me things quick as I could and left that cursed place. Ain’t no force on earth could make me spend another night there.  

But sometimes, when the moon is full and the wind howls just so, I still hear ’em—the wolves, callin’ to their Master. And I wonder if he’s still out there… waitin’.

17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”
I cannot afford to lose blood just at present; I have lost too much of late for my physical good, and then the prolonged strain of Lucy’s illness and its horrible phases is telling on me. I am over-excited and weary, and I need rest, rest, rest. Happily Van Helsing has not summoned me, so I need not forego my sleep; to-night I could not well do without it.

17 September. Night.—I write this and leave it to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me. This is an exact record of what took place to-night. I feel I am dying of weakness, and have barely strength to write, but it must be done if I die in the doing.
I went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as Dr. Van Helsing directed, and soon fell asleep.
I was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now I know so well. I was not afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in the next room—as Dr. Van Helsing said he would be—so that I might have called him. I tried to go to sleep, but could not. Then there came to me the old fear of sleep, and I determined to keep awake. Perversely sleep would try to come then when I did not want it; so, as I feared to be alone, I opened my door and called out: “Is there anybody there?” There was no answer. I was afraid to wake mother, and so closed my door again. Then outside in the shrubbery I heard a sort of howl like a dog’s, but more fierce and deeper. I went to the window and looked out, but could see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting its wings against the window. events.title: Lucy's Desperate Hours Alone with Death and Her Final Farewell
detailed_summary: Lucy regains consciousness after an awful, though seemingly short, period.
She hears a passing bell, dogs howling, and a nightingale singing, which she likens to her dead mother's comforting voice.
The maids, awakened by the sounds, enter Lucy's room and scream upon seeing Mrs. Westenra's body.
After Lucy gets up, they lay her mother's body on the bed, covered with a sheet.
Lucy, noticing their fright, directs them to the dining room for wine.
She places what flowers she has on her mother's breast.

When the maids don't return, Lucy finds them all unconscious on the dining room floor, breathing heavily, with a half-empty sherry decanter smelling of laudanum. She realizes someone drugged the servants.
Alone with her dead mother and the drugged servants, she hears the wolf howling outside the broken window.
The air seems full of floating specks, and the lights burn blue and dim.
Feeling her own death approaching, she decides to hide her written account in her breast.
She bids farewell to Arthur, praying for his well-being and for her own soul.

events.text_segment:
The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.
My heart sank when I saw what had happened. They all four lay helpless on the floor, breathing heavily. The decanter of sherry was on the table half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about. I was suspicious, and examined the decanter. It smelt of laudanum, and looking on the sideboard, I found that the bottle which mother’s doctor uses for her—oh! did use—was empty. What am I to do? what am I to do? I am back in the room with mother. I cannot leave her, and I am alone, save for the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged. Alone with the dead! I dare not go out, for I can hear the low howl of the wolf through the broken window.
The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from the window, and the lights burn blue and dim. What am I to do? God shield me from harm this night! I shall hide this paper in my breast, where they shall find it when they come to lay me out. My dear mother gone! It is time that I go too. Good-bye, dear Arthur, if I should not survive this night. God keep you, dear, and God help me!

events.title: Desperate Arrival and Grim Discovery at Hillingham
detailed_summary: Dr. Seward arrives at Hillingham on September 18th, finding the house unresponsive despite repeated knocking and ringing.
A growing sense of dread assails him, fearing the house might be another site of tragedy in the unfolding doom.
Unable to find any means of entry, as all windows and doors are secured, Seward is baffled.
Professor Van Helsing arrives shortly after, equally anxious and confirming he also sent a telegram that Seward just received.
Van Helsing expresses fear they are too late but resolves they must force entry quickly.
They break into the house through a kitchen window by sawing through iron bars and unfastening the sashes.
Inside, they discover four servant-women unconscious in the dining-room, the smell of laudanum indicating they were drugged.
They proceed to Lucy's room, pausing at the door with trepidation.
They find Lucy on the bed alongside her deceased mother, who has a look of terror on her face.
Lucy is extremely pale, her neck bare, showing the two small, mangled wounds, with the garlic flowers now on her mother's bosom.
Van Helsing quickly examines Lucy and exclaims that it is not too late, urging Seward to bring brandy immediately.

18 September.—I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early. Keeping my cab at the gate, I went up the avenue alone. I knocked gently and rang as quietly as possible, for I feared to disturb Lucy or her mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door. After a while, finding no response, I knocked and rang again; still no answer. I cursed the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an hour—for it was now ten o’clock—and so rang and knocked again, but more impatiently, but still without response. Hitherto I had blamed only the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing tight around us? Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come, too late? I knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of danger to Lucy, if she had had again one of those frightful relapses; and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry anywhere.
I could find no means of ingress. Every window and door was fastened and locked, and I returned baffled to the porch. As I did so, I heard the rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse’s feet. They stopped at the gate, and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue. When he saw me, he gasped out:—
“Then it was you, and just arrived. How is she? Are we too late? Did you not get my telegram?”
I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here, and that I could not make any one in the house hear me. He paused and raised his hat as he said solemnly:—
“Then I fear we are too late. God’s will be done!” With his usual recuperative energy, he went on: “Come. If there be no way open to get in, we must make one. Time is all in all to us now.”
We went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen window. The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case, and handing it to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window. I attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them. Then with a long, thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and opened the window. I helped the Professor in, and followed him. There was no one in the kitchen or in the servants’ rooms, which were close at hand. We tried all the rooms as we went along, and in the dining-room, dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four servant-women lying on the floor. There was no need to think them dead, for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt as to their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we moved away he said: “We can attend to them later.” Then we ascended to Lucy’s room. For an instant or two we paused at the door to listen, but there was no sound that we could hear. With white faces and trembling hands, we opened the door gently, and entered the room.
How shall I describe what we saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her mother. The latter lay farthest in, and she was covered with a white sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it. By her side lay Lucy, with face white and still more drawn. The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her mother’s bosom, and her throat was bare, showing the two little wounds which we had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled. Without a word the Professor bent over the bed, his head almost touching poor Lucy’s breast; then he gave a quick turn of his head, as of one who listens, and leaping to his feet, he cried out to me:—
“It is not yet too late! Quick! quick! Bring the brandy!”

18 September.—I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early. The air was crisp with the first hints of autumn, and the leaves had begun their slow, golden descent from the trees lining the road. My heart pounded with a mixture of dread and determination as the carriage rolled to a stop before the familiar gates.  

I was admitted without delay, though the servants moved with a quiet urgency that did little to ease my nerves. Miss Westenra, I was told, had taken a turn for the worse in the night. The pallor of her face when I entered her chamber struck me like a blow. She lay propped against the pillows, her once-vibrant eyes now dull with exhaustion. Yet, she managed a weak smile at my approach.  

"Lucy," I said, taking her hand. It was cold—unnaturally so. "How do you fare?"  

She sighed, her breath shallow. "Better now that you are here, Doctor. Though I fear sleep will not come easily again tonight."  

I examined her throat with care, noting with dismay the two small punctures that had not healed. If anything, they seemed more pronounced than before. The marks were faint, yet unmistakable—a cruel mockery of a lover’s bite. My mind raced with theories, each more dreadful than the last.  

"Have you had any strange dreams?" I asked, keeping my voice low.  

Her fingers tightened around mine. "Always the same," she whispered. "A great bat at the window... and then—oh, God!—then I feel him near me, though I cannot see his face. He speaks to me in a voice like velvet, promising rest, but when I wake, I am weaker than before."  

A chill ran through me. I had read of such things in the old texts, though I had dismissed them as superstition. Now, faced with Lucy’s suffering, I could no longer deny the possibility of forces beyond my understanding.  

I resolved then to stay the night. If some unseen predator stalked her, I would be there to confront it. The household retired early, and I took up my vigil in an armchair near the window, a revolver resting in my lap. The hours crawled by, the silence broken only by the occasional rustle of the curtains or the distant hoot of an owl.  

Then, just as the clock struck midnight, a shadow passed across the moonlit pane. My pulse quickened. A shape—dark and immense—alighted upon the sill with unnatural grace. I caught the gleam of eyes, red as embers, before the window slid open of its own accord.  

I raised my weapon, but before I could fire, a gust of wind extinguished the lamp, plunging the room into darkness. A laugh, low and mocking, echoed through the chamber.  

"Who are you?" I demanded, my voice steady despite the terror clawing at my throat.  

The answer came not in words, but in a presence so overwhelming that my limbs grew heavy, my will sapped as though by some unseen force. I fought to move, to cry out, but my body would not obey.  

Then, as suddenly as it had come, the presence withdrew. The window slammed shut, and the room was still once more. When I at last found the strength to light the lamp, Lucy lay pale as death, her breath so faint I feared she had slipped away.  

Yet by dawn, she stirred, her color slightly improved. It was as though the fiend had taken only enough to sustain her—to prolong her torment.  

I left Hillingham with my mind in turmoil. Whatever stalked Lucy was no mere illness, nor any creature of natural law. I must consult Van Helsing at once. If there is indeed a vampire among us, then God help us all.

I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found on the table. The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and I fancied that the narcotic was wearing off. I did not stay to make sure, but returned to Van Helsing. He rubbed the brandy, as on another occasion, on her lips and gums and on her wrists and the palms of her hands. He said to me:—
“I can do this, all that can be at the present. You go wake those maids. Flick them in the face with a wet towel, and flick them hard. Make them get heat and fire and a warm bath. This poor soul is nearly as cold as that beside her. She will need be heated before we can do anything more.”
I went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the women. The fourth was only a young girl, and the drug had evidently affected her more strongly, so I lifted her on the sofa and let her sleep. The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to them they cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner. I was stern with them, however, and would not let them talk. I told them that one life was bad enough to lose, and that if they delayed they would sacrifice Miss Lucy. So, sobbing and crying, they went about their way, half clad as they were, and prepared fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water. We got a bath and carried Lucy out as she was and placed her in it. Whilst we were busy chafing her limbs there was a knock at the hall door. One of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it. Then she returned and whispered to us that there was a gentleman who had come with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I bade her simply tell him that he must wait, for we could see no one now. She went away with the message, and, engrossed with our work, I clean forgot all about him.
I never saw in all my experience the Professor work in such deadly earnest. I knew—as he knew—that it was a stand-up fight with death, and in a pause told him so. He answered me in a way that I did not understand, but with the sternest look that his face could wear:—
“If that were all, I would stop here where we are now, and let her fade away into peace, for I see no light in life over her horizon.” He went on with his work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour.
Presently we both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to be of some effect. Lucy’s heart beat a trifle more audibly to the stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement. Van Helsing’s face almost beamed, and as we lifted her from the bath and rolled her in a hot sheet to dry her he said to me:—
“The first gain is ours! Check to the King!”
We took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid her in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down her throat. I noticed that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief round her throat. She was still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, we had ever seen her.
Van Helsing called in one of the women, and told her to stay with her and not to take her eyes off her till we returned, and then beckoned me out of the room.
“We must consult as to what is to be done,” he said as we descended the stairs. In the hall he opened the dining-room door, and we passed in, he closing the door carefully behind him. The shutters had been opened, but the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of death which the British woman of the lower classes always rigidly observes. The room was, therefore, dimly dark. It was, however, light enough for our purposes. Van Helsing’s sternness was somewhat relieved by a look of perplexity. He was evidently torturing his mind about something, so I waited for an instant, and he spoke:—
“What are we to do now? Where are we to turn for help? We must have another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl’s life won’t be worth an hour’s purchase. You are exhausted already; I am exhausted too. I fear to trust those women, even if they would have courage to submit. What are we to do for some one who will open his veins for her?”
“What’s the matter with me, anyhow?”
The voice came from the sofa across the room, and its tones brought relief and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris. Van Helsing started angrily at the first sound, but his face softened and a glad look came into his eyes as I cried out: “Quincey Morris!” and rushed towards him with outstretched hands.
“What brought you here?” I cried as our hands met.
“I guess Art is the cause.”
He handed me a telegram:—
“Have not heard from Seward for three days, and am terribly anxious. Cannot leave. Father still in same condition. Send me word how Lucy is. Do not delay.—Holmwood.”
“I think I came just in the nick of time. You know you have only to tell me what to do.”
Van Helsing strode forward, and took his hand, looking him straight in the eyes as he said:—
“A brave man’s blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in trouble. You’re a man and no mistake. Well, the devil may work against us for all he’s worth, but God sends us men when we want them.”

I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found on the table. The wine had been tampered with—of that I was certain—for the faintest trace of bitterness lingered on my tongue, a sinister whisper of some noxious substance. My heart pounded as I recalled the Count’s unnatural strength, his piercing eyes, and the way he seemed to move without sound. Was this his doing? Had he laced the drink to render me helpless, just as he had done to poor Jonathan Harker in his castle?

I set the glass aside, my hands trembling. The very air of this house seemed thick with menace, as though the walls themselves bore witness to unspeakable horrors. The candles flickered wildly, casting grotesque shadows that danced like specters across the ceiling. Outside, the wind howled through the trees, a mournful dirge that sent chills down my spine. I could not shake the feeling that I was being watched—that unseen eyes followed my every move.

Then, a sound—soft, almost imperceptible—reached my ears. A rustling, like the whisper of silk against stone. My breath caught in my throat as I turned toward the door. Had something moved in the hallway? I strained to listen, but the silence that followed was more terrifying than any noise. The dread that gripped me was paralyzing, yet I knew I could not remain idle. If the Count was near, if he sought to make me his next victim, I had to act.

With a resolve born of desperation, I seized the nearest candlestick, its heavy base a crude but effective weapon. I crept toward the door, my pulse roaring in my ears. The handle was cold beneath my fingers as I turned it slowly, inch by agonizing inch. The hinges groaned faintly as the door swung open, revealing the darkened corridor beyond. 

Nothing. 

The hallway was empty, yet the oppressive sense of another presence lingered. I stepped forward, my candle casting a feeble glow that did little to dispel the gloom. Then—a flicker of movement at the far end of the passage. A shadow, tall and gaunt, seemed to glide just beyond the reach of the light. My blood turned to ice. 

"Who's there?" I called, my voice unsteady. 

No answer came, but the shadow paused, as if considering me. Then, with unnatural swiftness, it vanished into the blackness. 

I knew then that I was not alone. The Count was here, in this house, and he was toying with me. The realization filled me with a terror so profound that my legs threatened to give way. Yet I could not flee—not without Lucy. I had sworn to protect her, and I would not abandon her to that monster’s clutches. 

Steeling myself, I advanced down the hallway, my grip tightening on the candlestick. Every creak of the floorboards beneath my feet sounded like a thunderclap in the stillness. The door to Lucy’s chamber stood ajar, and my heart lurched at the sight. Had he already reached her? 

I pushed the door open fully, my breath coming in ragged gasps. The room was bathed in moonlight, its pale glow illuminating the bed where Lucy lay. She was so still, so unnaturally pale, that for a dreadful moment I feared the worst. But then her chest rose faintly, and I nearly wept with relief. 

Yet my relief was short-lived. 

At the foot of the bed, half-hidden in shadow, stood a figure—tall, cloaked, his eyes burning with a malevolent light. The Count. 

He turned to me, his lips curling into a smile that revealed the sharp points of his fangs. "Ah, my dear friend," he murmured, his voice like velvet over steel. "You have come just in time to witness the final act." 

I raised the candlestick, my voice shaking but defiant. "Stay away from her!" 

He laughed, a sound that echoed with centuries of cruelty. "You think you can stop me? How amusing." 

Before I could react, he moved—faster than any mortal man—and seized my wrist with a grip like iron. The candlestick clattered to the floor as pain shot up my arm. His strength was inhuman, his presence suffocating. I struggled, but it was futile. 

Then, from the bed, a weak voice called out: "Arthur... help me..." 

Lucy’s eyes fluttered open, filled with terror and confusion. The sight of her suffering ignited a fury within me. With a desperate lunge, I tore free from the Count’s grasp and snatched up the fallen candlestick. 

"You will not have her!" I roared, swinging with all my might. 

The blow struck the Count’s temple, and he staggered back, his face contorted with rage. For the first time, I saw something like fear flicker in his eyes. But it was gone in an instant, replaced by a cold, calculating hatred. 

"This is not over," he hissed. Then, with a swirl of his cloak, he was gone—vanishing into the night as though he had never been there at all. 

I collapsed to my knees, gasping for breath. The room was silent once more, save for Lucy’s faint sobs. I crawled to her side, gathering her into my arms. 

"He will return," I whispered, more to myself than to her. "And when he does, we must be ready." 

For now, though, we had survived. But the battle was far from over. The Count’s evil knew no bounds, and I feared that the worst was yet to come.

events.title: Quincey's Transfusion, Lucy's Manuscript, and Growing Suspicions
detailed_summary: Quincey Morris undergoes the blood transfusion for Lucy.
Lucy's body does not respond as well to this transfusion as on previous occasions; her struggle back to life is frightful, though her heart and lung action improve.
Van Helsing administers a subcutaneous injection of morphia, and Lucy falls into a profound slumber.
While Seward attends to other matters, Van Helsing finds a piece of notepaper that had fallen from Lucy's breast during her transfer to the bath.
Van Helsing gives the paper to Seward, who reads it and is utterly bewildered by its contents; Van Helsing postpones any explanation.
Seward raises the issue of Mrs. Westenra's death certificate, proposing they certify her death from heart disease to avoid an inquest that could harm Lucy.
Van Helsing praises Seward's foresight and expresses deep appreciation for the friends willing to sacrifice for Lucy.
Seward informs Quincey of developments, and they agree to talk privately later. Seward then arranges the death registration and funeral.
Quincey later confronts Seward, expressing his deep affection for Lucy and his concern about her mysterious illness.
He reveals he has deduced that Seward, Van Helsing, and Arthur have all previously given blood.
Quincey recounts a chilling story from the Pampas about a mare killed by a vampire bat, drawing a parallel to Lucy's condition and asking what caused her blood loss.
Seward confirms Quincey's deductions about the transfusions and the timeline, admitting their complete bafflement about the cause.
Quincey, horrified by the implications, firmly pledges his assistance in any way required.

Once again we went through that ghastly operation. I have not the heart to go through with the details. Lucy had got a terrible shock and it told on her more than before, for though plenty of blood went into her veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as well as on the other occasions. Her struggle back into life was something frightful to see and hear. However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with good effect. Her faint became a profound slumber. The Professor watched whilst I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and sent one of the maids to pay off one of the cabmen who were waiting. I left Quincey lying down after having a glass of wine, and told the cook to get ready a good breakfast. Then a thought struck me, and I went back to the room where Lucy now was. When I came softly in, I found Van Helsing with a sheet or two of note-paper in his hand. He had evidently read it, and was thinking it over as he sat with his hand to his brow. There was a look of grim satisfaction in his face, as of one who has had a doubt solved. He handed me the paper saying only: “It dropped from Lucy’s breast when we carried her to the bath.”
When I had read it, I stood looking at the Professor, and after a pause asked him: “In God’s name, what does it all mean? Was she, or is she, mad; or what sort of horrible danger is it?” I was so bewildered that I did not know what to say more. Van Helsing put out his hand and took the paper, saying:—
“Do not trouble about it now. Forget it for the present. You shall know and understand it all in good time; but it will be later. And now what is it that you came to me to say?” This brought me back to fact, and I was all myself again.
“I came to speak about the certificate of death. If we do not act properly and wisely, there may be an inquest, and that paper would have to be produced. I am in hopes that we need have no inquest, for if we had it would surely kill poor Lucy, if nothing else did. I know, and you know, and the other doctor who attended her knows, that Mrs. Westenra had disease of the heart, and we can certify that she died of it. Let us fill up the certificate at once, and I shall take it myself to the registrar and go on to the undertaker.”
“Good, oh my friend John! Well thought of! Truly Miss Lucy, if she be sad in the foes that beset her, is at least happy in the friends that love her. One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides one old man. Ah yes, I know, friend John; I am not blind! I love you all the more for it! Now go.”
In the hall I met Quincey Morris, with a telegram for Arthur telling him that Mrs. Westenra was dead; that Lucy also had been ill, but was now going on better; and that Van Helsing and I were with her. I told him where I was going, and he hurried me out, but as I was going said:—
“When you come back, Jack, may I have two words with you all to ourselves?” I nodded in reply and went out. I found no difficulty about the registration, and arranged with the local undertaker to come up in the evening to measure for the coffin and to make arrangements.
When I got back Quincey was waiting for me. I told him I would see him as soon as I knew about Lucy, and went up to her room. She was still sleeping, and the Professor seemingly had not moved from his seat at her side. From his putting his finger to his lips, I gathered that he expected her to wake before long and was afraid of forestalling nature. So I went down to Quincey and took him into the breakfast-room, where the blinds were not drawn down, and which was a little more cheerful, or rather less cheerless, than the other rooms. When we were alone, he said to me:—
“Jack Seward, I don’t want to shove myself in anywhere where I’ve no right to be; but this is no ordinary case. You know I loved that girl and wanted to marry her; but, although that’s all past and gone, I can’t help feeling anxious about her all the same. What is it that’s wrong with her? The Dutchman—and a fine old fellow he is; I can see that—said, that time you two came into the room, that you must have another transfusion of blood, and that both you and he were exhausted. Now I know well that you medical men speak in camera, and that a man must not expect to know what they consult about in private. But this is no common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part. Is not that so?”
“That’s so,” I said, and he went on:—
“I take it that both you and Van Helsing had done already what I did to-day. Is not that so?”
“That’s so.”
“And I guess Art was in it too. When I saw him four days ago down at his own place he looked queer. I have not seen anything pulled down so quick since I was on the Pampas and had a mare that I was fond of go to grass all in a night. One of those big bats that they call vampires had got at her in the night, and what with his gorge and the vein left open, there wasn’t enough blood in her to let her stand up, and I had to put a bullet through her as she lay. Jack, if you may tell me without betraying confidence, Arthur was the first, is not that so?” As he spoke the poor fellow looked terribly anxious. He was in a torture of suspense regarding the woman he loved, and his utter ignorance of the terrible mystery which seemed to surround her intensified his pain. His very heart was bleeding, and it took all the manhood of him—and there was a royal lot of it, too—to keep him from breaking down. I paused before answering, for I felt that I must not betray anything which the Professor wished kept secret; but already he knew so much, and guessed so much, that there could be no reason for not answering, so I answered in the same phrase: “That’s so.”
“And how long has this been going on?”
“About ten days.”
“Ten days! Then I guess, Jack Seward, that that poor pretty creature that we all love has had put into her veins within that time the blood of four strong men. Man alive, her whole body wouldn’t hold it.” Then, coming close to me, he spoke in a fierce half-whisper: “What took it out?”
I shook my head. “That,” I said, “is the crux. Van Helsing is simply frantic about it, and I am at my wits’ end. I can’t even hazard a guess. There has been a series of little circumstances which have thrown out all our calculations as to Lucy being properly watched. But these shall not occur again. Here we stay until all be well—or ill.” Quincey held out his hand. “Count me in,” he said. “You and the Dutchman will tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.”

**CHAPTER XII  
DR. SEWARD’S DIARY**  

*18 September.*—Once again we went through that ghastly operation. I could not consent to it the last time without a shudder, for I felt that we were in some way helping to murder the poor girl, though it was to save her. The agony of the operation was terrible, and though she did not scream, her face was drawn and distorted with pain. But it was over at last, and she sank into exhaustion so deep that it seemed as if she would never wake again.  

Van Helsing placed a subcutaneous injection of morphia, and after a while she fell into a deep sleep. Then he and I went into the next room, leaving Quincey Morris to watch her. When we were alone, he said to me:—  

“John, there is something very strange about this. I found on Lucy’s breast, when I was undressing her to put her into the bath, a piece of paper. It had evidently fallen from her nightdress when we lifted her. Here it is. Read it.”  

He handed me a folded piece of notepaper. I opened it and read:—  

*“Look out for D. He is near. I know it. I have seen him. He is sneaking in somewhere. Oh, do be careful!”*  

I looked at Van Helsing, and he saw the bewilderment on my face. He said:—  

“I do not wish to add to your perplexity at present, but I think it well that you should know this. Later on I may explain.”  

I said nothing, but stood thinking. Then an idea struck me. “Van Helsing,” I said, “we must have a death certificate. There must be no inquest. It would kill poor Lucy if she knew.”  

He nodded and said:—  

“You are quite right. It would be terrible for her. And yet, if there were an inquest, it might be worse. The whole story would have to come out—the blood, and the rest of it. No, we must avoid that. I will see the coroner myself. He is a friend of mine, and he will stretch a point if I ask him.”  

I thanked him, and he went away to make the arrangements.  

When he had gone, I went to Quincey Morris and told him what had happened. He was much moved, and said:—  

“This is a bad business. I don’t like it. There’s something behind it all, and I mean to find out what it is. But in the meantime, we must all stand together.”  

I agreed, and we arranged that he should come to my rooms that night, and we would talk the matter over.  

Later in the day, when the undertakers had done their work, and Lucy was lying in her coffin, I went to the registrar and gave the necessary certificate. Then I went to the undertaker’s and arranged for the funeral.  

That night Quincey came to my rooms, as arranged. He was very grave, and said:—  

“I’ve been thinking a lot about this business, and I don’t like it. There’s something wrong—something very wrong. I can’t make it out, but I feel it. And I’m going to find out what it is.”  

I told him that I felt the same, but that we must be careful not to alarm Lucy.  

“Oh, as to that,” he said, “I’ve been watching her, and I’ve seen enough to know that she’s in some awful danger. And I’m going to help her, if I can.”  

Then he told me a strange story of something that had happened to him in the Pampas. He had seen a mare killed by a vampire bat, and the description of the wounds was horribly like those on Lucy’s throat.  

“Now, look here,” he said, “you’ve given her your blood, and Van Helsing has given his, and Arthur has given his. And yet she’s no better. What does it mean?”  

I told him that we were all completely puzzled, and that we could not account for the loss of blood.  

He looked at me fixedly and said:—  

“Then you think it’s something supernatural?”  

I hesitated, and then said:—  

“I don’t know what to think. But whatever it is, we must fight it.”  

He held out his hand.  

“Count me in,” he said. “We’re up against something big, and we’ll need all the help we can get.”  

---

Once again we went through that ghastly operation. The air was thick with the scent of blood and the acrid tang of fear. The candles flickered ominously, casting long, wavering shadows upon the stone walls of the crypt. The Count’s eyes burned with a malevolent fire as he loomed over us, his presence suffocating, his will unyielding.  

I could feel my strength ebbing away, my very life force draining as the unholy ritual unfolded. Mina, my dear Mina, lay pale and trembling beside me, her once-vibrant spirit now crushed beneath the weight of Dracula’s curse. Her breath came in shallow gasps, and though she fought valiantly, I could see the despair creeping into her eyes.  

Van Helsing, ever the stalwart leader, worked with grim determination, his hands steady despite the horror before us. He muttered prayers under his breath, the words a desperate plea for divine intervention. But even his faith seemed shaken, for the forces arrayed against us were of a darkness so profound that it threatened to swallow us whole.  

Jonathan Harker, gaunt and hollow-eyed from his own ordeal, clutched his crucifix as though it were the only thing tethering him to sanity. His gaze never left the Count, his hatred a palpable thing, a fire that refused to be extinguished. Yet even his resolve wavered as the reality of our situation pressed in upon us.  

Quincey Morris, ever the man of action, stood ready with his Bowie knife, his jaw set in defiance. But what good were steel and courage against a creature who defied the very laws of nature?  

And then there was Arthur Holmwood, poor Arthur, who had already lost so much. His grief for Lucy was a wound that would never heal, and now he faced the prospect of losing Mina as well. His hands trembled as he held the stake, the instrument that had once freed Lucy from her torment. Would he be forced to wield it again? The thought was unbearable.  

The Count’s laughter echoed through the chamber, a sound like the scraping of bones against stone. "Fools," he hissed, his voice dripping with contempt. "You think to defy me? To thwart the will of the undead? You are but insects beneath my heel."  

Van Helsing stepped forward, his voice steady despite the terror that gripped us all. "We may be mortal, Dracula, but we are not without power. The light of God still shines upon us, and by His grace, we shall see you destroyed."  

The Count’s smile was a thing of nightmares. "Then let us see whose will is stronger."  

With a sudden, inhuman speed, he lunged forward, his fingers like claws, his fangs bared. Quincey was the first to react, his knife flashing in the dim light as he struck. But the Count was like mist, his form dissolving and reforming with unnatural ease. The blade passed harmlessly through him, and before Quincey could react, Dracula seized him by the throat, lifting him effortlessly off the ground.  

"No!" Arthur cried, rushing forward with the stake. But the Count merely backhanded him, sending him sprawling across the cold stone floor.  

Mina let out a choked sob, her strength failing. "Please…" she whispered, her voice barely audible. "Please, let them go."  

The Count turned his gaze upon her, his expression softening for the briefest moment. "Ah, my dear Mina," he murmured, his voice almost tender. "You alone among them understand the truth. You alone have felt the kiss of the night. Why resist? Embrace what you are destined to become."  

I could bear it no longer. Summoning the last of my strength, I threw myself at him, my fists striking uselessly against his immovable form. He regarded me with amusement before swatting me aside like a bothersome fly. Pain exploded through my body as I crashed into the wall, my vision swimming.  

Van Helsing, ever resourceful, seized the moment to produce a vial of holy water. With a swift motion, he flung its contents at the Count. The droplets struck his flesh like acid, hissing and smoking as they burned into him. The Count let out a roar of agony, releasing Quincey as he staggered back.  

"Now!" Van Helsing shouted.  

Jonathan and Arthur surged forward, their weapons raised. But the Count was not so easily defeated. With a snarl, he vanished into the shadows, his laughter lingering like a curse in the air.  

Silence fell over the crypt, broken only by our ragged breathing. We had survived—barely—but the cost was written on each of our faces. Mina lay unconscious, her skin deathly pale, her pulse faint. Quincey clutched his throat, his breath coming in ragged gasps. Arthur knelt beside Mina, his face a mask of anguish.  

Van Helsing wiped the sweat from his brow, his expression grim. "We must act quickly," he said. "The Count will not rest, and neither can we. The final battle draws near."  

I looked around at my companions, their faces etched with exhaustion and despair. Yet despite it all, there was a flicker of defiance in their eyes. We had come too far to surrender now.  

The night was far from over, and the worst was yet to come. But as long as breath remained in our bodies, we would fight. For Mina. For Lucy. For all those who had fallen to the vampire’s curse.  

We would see this through to the end, no matter the cost.  

And so, once again, we prepared ourselves for the ghastly ordeal that lay ahead.

events.title: Lucy's Waking Distress and Symbolic Manuscript Destruction
detailed_summary: Lucy awakens late in the afternoon, her first action being to feel for the manuscript on her breast, which Van Helsing had carefully replaced.
She shows gladness upon seeing Van Helsing and Seward but then shudders, crying out as she fully comprehends her mother's death.
Seward and Van Helsing try to comfort her, and their promise that one or both will remain with her constantly seems to soothe her somewhat.
As dusk approaches, Lucy dozes off. While still asleep, she takes the paper from her breast and tears it in two.
Van Helsing retrieves the pieces, but Lucy continues the tearing motion with her hands as if the paper were still there, finally opening them as if scattering fragments.
Van Helsing observes this peculiar action with surprise and thoughtfulness but makes no comment.

events.text_segment: When she woke late in the afternoon, Lucy’s first movement was to feel in her breast, and, to my surprise, produced the paper which Van Helsing had given me to read. The careful Professor had replaced it where it had come from, lest on waking she should be alarmed. Her eye then lit on Van Helsing and on me too, and gladdened. Then she looked around the room, and seeing where she was, shuddered; she gave a loud cry, and put her poor thin hands before her pale face. We both understood what that meant—that she had realised to the full her mother’s death; so we tried what we could to comfort her. Doubtless sympathy eased her somewhat, but she was very low in thought and spirit, and wept silently and weakly for a long time. We told her that either or both of us would now remain with her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her. Towards dusk she fell into a doze. Here a very odd thing occurred. Whilst still asleep she took the paper from her breast and tore it in two. Van Helsing stepped over and took the pieces from her. All the same, however, she went on with the action of tearing, as though the material were still in her hands; finally she lifted her hands and opened them as though scattering the fragments. Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his brows gathered as if in thought, but he said nothing.

events.text_segment:
19 September.—All last night she slept fitfully, being always afraid to sleep, and something weaker when she woke from it. The Professor and I took it in turns to watch, and we never left her for a moment unattended. Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I knew that all night long he patrolled round and round the house.
When the day came, its searching light showed the ravages in poor Lucy’s strength. She was hardly able to turn her head, and the little nourishment which she could take seemed to do her no good. At times she slept, and both Van Helsing and I noticed the difference in her, between sleeping and waking. Whilst asleep she looked stronger, although more haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale gums drawn back from the teeth, which thus looked positively longer and sharper than usual; when she woke the softness of her eyes evidently changed the expression, for she looked her own self, although a dying one. In the afternoon she asked for Arthur, and we telegraphed for him. Quincey went off to meet him at the station.
When he arrived it was nearly six o’clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks. When he saw her, Arthur was simply choking with emotion, and none of us could speak. In the hours that had passed, the fits of sleep, or the comatose condition that passed for it, had grown more frequent, so that the pauses when conversation was possible were shortened. Arthur’s presence, however, seemed to act as a stimulant; she rallied a little, and spoke to him more brightly than she had done since we arrived. He too pulled himself together, and spoke as cheerily as he could, so that the best was made of everything.
It was now nearly one o’clock, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her. I am to relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am entering this on Lucy’s phonograph. Until six o’clock they are to try to rest. I fear that to-morrow will end our watching, for the shock has been too great; the poor child cannot rally. God help us all.
